STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 16, 2021
Ottawa County DHHS
12185 James Street
Holland, MI 49424
RE: License #: CP700201350
Ottawa County DHHS
12185 James Street
Holland, MI 49424
Dear Ms. Spanjer:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
7/12-7/16/2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP700201350
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Kendra Spanjer, Administrator
Name of Facility: Ottawa County DHHS
Facility Address: 12185 James Street
Holland, MI 49424
Facility Telephone #: (616) 394-7200
Original Issuance Date: 09/01/1991
Service Types: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): July 12-16, 2021

Reviewed

METHODS OF INSPECTION – B. Analyst

3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
1 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained the document on which the
required information is provided to the foster parents (DHS-3307) but did not have
any signatures or dates and was uploaded 3 months after the placement.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
1 of 11 total open youth files reviewed contained 1 service plan that was completed
outside of the required timeframe. The report was for an open foster care case and
was 1 day late.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/8/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 10/20/2020
8/21/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 9/3/2019
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at
least once every month.
4

1 of 11 total open youth files reviewed did not contain documentation of a home visit
for the month of November 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as FOM 722-6H
8/21/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 9/3/2019
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Policy requirements
except for the following:
FOM 722-08C FOSTER CARE - PARENT-AGENCY TREATMENT PLAN &
P. 4 SERVICE AGREEMENT
Signatures- When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee.
3 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained reports that did not contain all
signatures as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED, previously cited as ISEP 6.33
10/8/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 10/20/2020
8/21/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 9/3/2019
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
P. 5 & 12 & 16
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
5

Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and
the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
2 of 11 total open case files reviewed did not meet the FTM policy requirements for
service plan development and placement change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/8/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 10/20/2020
8/21/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 9/3/2019
FOM 722-06H CASE CONTACTS
P. 5 & 11
CONTACT WITH CHILD'S CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in the
caregiver’s home each calendar month. If there is more than one
caregiver, such as a primary and secondary caregiver, the
caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the secondary
caregiver in the home at least once each quarter.
CHILD IN A PARENTAL PLACEMENT
During each subsequent calendar month, the primary caseworker
must have at least two face-to-face contacts in the home with the
family until case closure.
6

1 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained social work contacts
documenting that only one caregiver was present for caregiver home visits for the
period spanning 2/2021 – 6/2021.
1 of 8 foster care case files reviewed in which the youth was placed in a parental
home contained documentation indicating that only 1 home visit was completed in
the parental home in the month of February.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/21/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 9/3/2019
FOM 722-03C OLDER YOUTH: PREPARATION, PLACEMENT, AND
DISCHARGE
Life Skills Assessment - The Casey Life Skills Assessment must
be completed within 90 days of a youth turning 14, and annually
thereafter. For youth who are 14 or older when they enter care,
the assessment should be completed within 90 days of entering
care.
For youth who are placed in residential, it is the residential case
worker who ensures the Casey Life Skills Assessment if
completed.
Placement in independent living may be an acceptable living
arrangement for youth 16 years or older. Prior to placement in
independent living, the caseworker must assess the youth, with
the Casey Life Skills Assessment, as being prepared for
independent living and demonstrate a pattern of mature
decision making.
2 of 3 Independent Living files reviewed did not contain Casey Life Skills
documentation completed as required.
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
P. 1
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
7

COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure - Within
three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business days of
change in caseworker and/or organization.
4 of 12 total foster care files reviewed (8 open, 4 closed) did not contain action
summaries complete as required. One file was missing an action summary for an
organization change, one file had two action summaries for a placement changes
that were completed outside of the required timeframe, and two closed files were
missing action summaries for case closure.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as 722-09C
10/8/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 10/20/2020
8/21/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 9/3/2019
FOM 722-09 FOSTER CARE - UPDATED SERVICE PLAN
p. 25
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
1 of 12 open case files (8 FC, 3 IL) contained service plans approved outside of the
required timeframe. One service plan was approved 1 day late and the other 8 days
late.
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following
8

All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
2 of 8 open foster case files reviewed did not contain medical passports as required.
One file did not have a medical passport at placement or quarterly updates, one was
missing a medical passport for a placement change.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED previously cited as ISEP 6.49
10/8/2020 INTERIM, CAP Approved 10/20/2020
8/21/2019 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 9/3/2019
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 One file contained Home Visit & Parenting Time contacts which were sparse
& did not include all required information during each visit
 All signed documents should include dates of signature
 Contact with caregivers shall be documented clearly in the case contacts at
the required intervals
 When a case transfers from one agency to another the previous worker and
the new work shall sign the Medical Passport at case transfer
 A clear photo in which the youth can be identified must be in the file
 When the case of youth 14 or over transfers from one agency to another, the
Casey Life Skills must be current
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 While policy does not require both foster parents in a two-parent foster parent
foster home sign each treatment plan, it is best practice to have them both to
ensure they understand and agree to the plan requirements
9

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
Chief Administrator Assessment – I reviewed the Chief Administrator Assessment
which indicated that while the COVID-19 pandemic restrictions and staff turnover
and specific staff performance issues made compliance difficult, the CAP submitted
following the 2020 licensing inspection has had a positive impact resulting in
improved compliance overall. The findings of this inspection corroborate the
assessment, with the addition of concerns related to specific staff performance
issues that were addressed as timely as possible.
CHRI - On 7/13/2021 I virtually viewed the storage of the key and the locked storage
area for CHRI information. I also viewed the dissemination and destruction logs
stored in this secure area.
Other Document Review - On 7/13/2021 I reviewed the agency’s organization chart
and case ratios. While the agency has had a significant staffing changes, they have
maintained staffing & case assignment ratios.
Staff Interviews – The staff reported that there has been regular communication
and support provided by supervision despite remote work. No concerns were
identified during the interviews.
VII. Analyst Findings
The DCWL Analyst identified one safety concern in an unlicensed relative caregiver
home.
Safety Alert: Home did not have a smoke detector located on the second level of the
home where the children’s bedrooms were located and the children in the home could
not identify a safety plan in case of fire.
Resolution: Photos of installed smoke detectors and completed emergency safety
plan which was posted on the family’s refrigerator were provided.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
10

July 16, 2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 16, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
